subject: Re: Deep Equals of two JavaBeans
msgSnippet: Hi Joe, I m not looking for a solution to a problem, rather comments on the class I ve implemented that does a deep equals comparison. I already use BeanUtils
messageBody:
Hi Joe,

I'm not looking for a solution to a problem, rather comments on the
class I've implemented that does a deep equals comparison. I already
use BeanUtils in a method to examine complex objects:

private static void evaluateComplexProperty(Object expected,
Object actual) {
Map expectedProps = null, actualProps = null;
try {
expectedProps = PropertyUtils.describe(expected);
actualProps = PropertyUtils.describe(actual);
// not to thrilled about this, better way??
expectedProps.remove("class");
actualProps.remove("class");
} catch (Exception ex) {
ex.printStackTrace();
logger.error(ex);
}

evaluateMapProperty(expectedProps, actualProps);
}

The problem with implementing equals the way you did is that it isn't
always suitable or correct to compare beans property-for-property. It
is useful to do so in say, a database testcase where you want to
ensure that a table's columns map to each of your bean's properties.

I appreciate the post, but it would be great it you could comment on
the code I wrote and help me make it better. Right now, the biggest
problem is that it outputs kindof crappy error messages. Also, one
person told me my strategy to detect cycles is weak, but they didn't
give me a better solution. I sure would love one :-)

Thanks!
